unnormalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra – Widespread logistics delays are severely impacting Indian manufacturers, leading to production bottlenecks and rising costs. A recent report by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) indicates that delivery times have increased by an average of 25% in the last quarter, particularly affecting SMEs in regions like Surat and Tirupur.
normalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra – Widespread logistics delays are severely impacting Indian manufacturers, leading to production bottlenecks and rising costs. A recent report by the Confederation of Indian Industry (C I I) indicates that delivery times have increased by an average of twenty five percent in the last quarter, particularly affecting S M Es in regions like Surat and Tirupur.

unnormalised: Dr. Meera Patel, an economist at the IIM Ahmedabad, attributes the delays to infrastructure bottlenecks, port congestion (especially at JNPT), and a shortage of skilled truck drivers exacerbated by the upcoming festive season. Many companies are now resorting to costly air freight to meet export commitments, eating into profit margins.

unnormalised: "Delays are adding significantly to our overheads," laments Rajesh Sharma, owner of a textile factory in Ludhiana, Punjab. "We're losing orders as buyers prefer quicker turnaround times." The delays also affect the availability of raw materials, forcing manufacturers to maintain larger inventories, tying up capital. Some reports indicate warehouses are experiencing up to 30% capacity shortfall. Developers are rushing to meet demand with new logistics parks planned, offering millions of sq ft of space. The Rs. 500 crore project near Nagpur is expected to alleviate some pressure, but systemic reforms are needed. Further analysis suggests rail freight can significantly improve situation.
